results.title: How do you spell my name in chinese?

results.title: How do you drive?
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais, Walford Hewitson and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Released for general use as a public service by the Royal Canadian Air Force, this film demonstrates driving skills as taught at a National Defence Driving School. It follows the course of instruction of a new driver, and shows basic rules for handling a car under a variety of conditions, from turning a corner to halting a skid on ice.

results.title: How do children think?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Discovery and Experience”.
Discusses Piaget’s research and theories of the main periods of development in children. To advance beyond the stage of primitive concrete operations, children need opportunities for the kind of work they do in primary schools, based on activity, discussion, and the growth of social relationships.

results.title: How did she do it? A literary enquiry into the worldwide appeal of Agatha Christie
results.creator_credit: Toby Wallis, Stephen Hearst and Orsino Productions
results.brief_description: Structured as a mystery novel in itself, this documentary presented by Agatha Christie biographer, Janet Morgan, attempts to unravel the appeal and inspiration behind the Queen of crime. The program includes interviews with fellow crime writer P.D. James (who is not necessarily a big fan of the writer but can appreciate the “fairy tale” aspect to the work), editors, performers, critics and an international vox pop. The program looks at the tenets of Christie’s novels and provides solid biographical details to ascertain why she was compelled to write what she did so prolifically. Narrated by Melvyn Bragg.
results.title_for_label: How did she do it? A literary enquiry into the worldwide appeal of Agatha Christie

results.title: How death came to earth
results.brief_description: A legend from India, interpreted on film by a film-maker from India. It is a story of gods and men, of suns and moons and earth, interpreted with an animation style and a richness of colour and design as arresting to the eye as the story and the music are to the ear. Sometimes the illustrations are painted on cells, sometimes the figures are cut-outs moving across shining grounds, but always the pace is gentle, inevitable.

results.title: How cultures are studied
results.creator_credit: Harry Ratner, Ira R. Abrams, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Faces of culture”.
In order to make credible studies of other cultures, the anthropologist must undertake field work. This program details the work of Napoleon A. Chagnon with the Yanamamo Indians of Venezuela, with whom he lived for extended periods of time. Professor Chagnon stresses the need for the anthropologist to participate in the culture he is studying and to abide by its rules. He describes the methods of data collection which he used in order to build up a comprehensive picture of this society as it was before it would inevitably become contaminated by the outside world. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: How clear the hot springs bubble
results.brief_description: Iceland is a country of great contrasts. Under glaciers and close by ice-capped peaks are many examples of thermal activity. In the volcanic belt which stretches across the island there are high temperature zones with bubbling mud pools. These springs are used for swimming pools, hot houses for growing vegetables and flowers and for heating homes.

results.title: How Britain votes
results.brief_description: The General Election of 1950 won by Atlee, is taken as an example to illustrate the functioning of the British electoral system. Footage of the election machinery is shown; the selection of candidate; the work of his local election agent; canvassing the electorate; policing; the work of the returning officer; Polling Day; announcement of the results; State opening of Parliament by George V.
